channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: American Inmate in North Korea Asks for High-Level U.S. Visit
item.description: An American imprisoned in North Korea has asked Washington to send a high-ranking official to help free him, according to video footage made public on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Israel Intercepts Rocket Headed for Resort City
item.description: Islamic militants took credit for a missile fired from the Sinai Peninsula in Egypt, as Israel’s Iron Dome missile shield was used to defend Eilat for the first time.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: U.S.C.I.R.F. Vice-chairwoman Katrina Lantos Swett
item.description: A leading official at the U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom talks about their insistence on keeping Gujarat Chief Minister Narendra Modi off American soil.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MAROOSHA MUZAFFAR
item.media:description: Katrina Lantos Swett in this Aug. 24, 2010 photo.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Tunisia: Military Strikes Militants Near Algeria
item.description: Tunisia on Monday carried out airstrikes on Islamist militants holed up in the Mount Chaambi area near the border with Algeria, an army official said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: U.S. Calls for Activist’s Release
item.description: The United States on Monday urged Bangladesh to free the human rights activist Adilur Rahman Khan, saying his detention had a “chilling effect” on civil society.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: U.N. Envoy Visits Troubled State
item.description: A human rights envoy on Monday visited Rakhine days after the police opened fire on protesters seeking access to the body of a Rohingya Muslim fisherman.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Kerry and Colombia Leaders Discuss Guerrilla War and Spying
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry sought to offer support for negotiations aimed at ending that country’s guerrilla war and to ease concerns over the N.S.A.’s surveillance.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: N.S.A. Leaks Make Plan for Cyberdefense Unlikely
item.description: The National Security Agency has lobbied to deploy a “Star Wars” defense for America’s computer networks, but officials said the plan had little chance of moving forward.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Arms Shipments Seen From Sudan to Syria Rebels
item.description: Syrian rebels have found an unlikely source for arms in Sudan, whose government sold the weapons to Qatar, which arranged delivery through Turkey, Western officials and the rebels said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: In an image taken from the Internet, a Syrian rebel with what appeared to be a Chinese-made FN-6 antiaircraft missile.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Mali: A Concession and a New Leader
item.description: Ibrahim Boubacar Keita won Mali’s presidency after his opponent conceded defeat Monday even before official results of Sunday’s runoff election were announced.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Bombings Claim at Least 26 Lives
item.description: Three explosions, including a suicide bombing in a cafe, killed at least 26 people in central and western Iraq on Monday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Mugabe Rails Against Defeated Rivals in Zimbabwe Elections
item.description: In his first public speech since declaring victory in disputed elections, President Robert G. Mugabe dismissed his main challenger in scathing language.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: President Robert G. Mugabe of Zimbabwe at the Heroes’ Day gathering in Harare on Monday.

item.title: Russia Detains Migrant Workers
item.description: The detentions have exposed the complexity and corruption of Russia’s labor market and tapped into the country’s simmering ethnic animosity.

item.title: Timing of Israeli Housing Plans May Be Part of a Political Calculation
item.description: Israel’s announcement this week that it was building over 1,000 housing units in East Jerusalem and the West Bank appeared to be partly a move to satisfy many Israelis before it released 26 Palestinian prisoners.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The mother, left, of a Palestinian prisoner, Ateya Abu Moussa, pictured on wall, on hearing that Israel would free him.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Olympics’ Leadership Mess
item.description: The International Olympic Committee needs a president who cares about human rights.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MINKY WORDEN

item.title: Russia Steps Up Raids Against Migrants
item.description: The raids have reportedly ensnared nearly 1,500 foreigners, including detainees being held in a Moscow tent camp under conditions that Human Rights Watch called inhuman.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hundreds of Vietnamese were among those rounded up in Russia and sent to a temporary detention camp in Moscow.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Rivals Exchange Accusations
item.description: Pakistan accused Indian troops of shelling its territory along the disputed Kashmir border on Monday and killing a civilian.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Gunmen Kill 56 in Northeast
item.description: Gunmen killed 44 worshipers in a mosque in northeastern Nigeria on Sunday, a day after 12 people were shot dead in a village nearby, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Prague Journal: On the Crony Safari, a Tour of a City’s Corruption
item.description: Between trips to medieval palaces and bridges, visitors to Prague can take a bus tour showcasing the country’s culture of lawlessness and corruption, and nibble on cookies labeled “presidential pardon.”
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Milan Bures for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: While the Prague Castle, above, is a must-see for visitors, a bus tour of a variety of city sites known for corruption has been a growing tourist attraction, according to the tour operators.

item.title: Rebel Chief in Syria Visits Assad’s Home Region
item.description: In a video, the commander of the Free Syrian Army said he was visiting President Bashar al-Assad’s home province to see the “accomplishments” of rebels, who have seized villages in the area.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: In Move for Economy, Mexican President Seeks Foreign Investment in Energy
item.description: President Enrique Peña Nieto proposed opening his country’s historically closed energy industry to private companies so that they might pump for oil.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: President Enrique Peña Nieto's plan would rewrite two amendments to the Constitution and challenges Mexico’s sovereignty over its energy resources.

item.title: Family Seeks Compensation for British Businessman’s Mysterious Death in China
item.description: Neil Heywood’s wife and mother are pressing for payment from the family of the woman convicted in his poisoning.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Neil Heywood at a gallery in Beijing in 2011.

item.title: Syrian War Shapes Trip by Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff
item.description: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey is visiting Israel and Jordan to discuss what further American aid could help contain the Syria conflict.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER

item.title: The Lede: Oprah Winfrey and the Handbag She Couldn’t Have
item.description: Oprah Winfrey said a saleswoman steered her away from a Tom Ford crocodile handbag in a locked case, priced at 35,000 francs, or about $38,000, while she was shopping at a luxury store in Switzerland.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Mexico Proposes Private Firms in Oil Industry
item.description: Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto proposed on Monday lifting a decades-old ban on private companies investing in the state-run oil industry, a cornerstone of Mexico's national pride that's seen production plummet in recent decades.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
